JUDGES: Giovanni Bonello;Ján Šikuta;Lech Garlicki;Ledi Bianku;Nicolas Bratza;Päivi Hirvelä
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE in GPE . He currently lives in GPE . He is of NORP ethnicity .

CARDINAL . The applicant entered GPE clandestinely on DATE and claimed asylum DATE . He stated that he feared ill - treatment in GPE by the GPE army and ORG ( “ the NORP ” ) . He explained that he had been arrested and detained by the army on CARDINAL occasions DATE on suspicion of involvement with the NORP . Following his last detention he went into hiding until his family managed to fund his journey to GPE . He feared the NORP on account of their adverse interest in his father who had done some work for the army . They had also tried to recruit the applicant on CARDINAL occasions in DATE .

CARDINAL . His claim was refused by the Secretary of ORG on DATE . His appeal against that decision was heard and dismissed by an Adjudicator on DATE . It was found that the applicant ’s account was credible : namely , he had been arrested by the army on some CARDINAL occasions DATE on suspicion of his involvement with the NORP . He was detained for CARDINAL on the first occasion and for DATE on the last . There was no evidence as to how long the other periods of detention had lasted . On each occasion he was released without charge . During CARDINAL or possibly more of these periods of detention he was ill - treated and his legs had scars from being beaten with batons . According to the Adjudicator , it may have been that the arrests took place in the course of round - ups . During the DATE detention the applicant was photographed and his fingerprints were taken and his father signed certain papers in order to secure his release . He went into hiding in a temple and wanted to leave GPE at that stage but it took time for his mother to obtain money from his brother to pay the agent for his departure .

CARDINAL . NORP However , the Adjudicator found that the applicant ’s fear of ill - treatment by the army upon his return was unjustified . It was noted that , since his departure from GPE , there had been a ceasefire between the army and the NORP for a considerable time , checkpoints had been dismantled , and the ORG had been able to open political offices and roads in the north . It was unlikely that he would attract any interest on the part of the authorities upon his return . Even if the record of his arrests was found it would be seen that he had been held for short periods and released without charge on each occasion . There was no record that he had ever been involved with the NORP or that he had ever been wanted by the authorities . There was no reason why he should be strip - searched on return and , even if his scars were found , they would not cause the authorities to take an interest in him , certainly not to the extent of detaining and ill - treating him .

CARDINAL . As to his fear of the NORP , the Adjudicator appeared to accept that the applicant ’s brother had done non - combative work for the NORP , though he was never a member . He , the brother , had been arrested by the army but never charged and had left GPE for GPE in DATE . It was found unlikely that the ORG would still have any interest in the applicant and if he was settled in GPE it would be unlikely that they could track him down . In any event , he could apply to the authorities for protection . As to his argument that he was in need of psychiatric treatment as a result of post - traumatic stress disorder , it was found that adequate treatment would be available in GPE .

CARDINAL . He was issued with removal directions for DATE and made further representations attempting to lodge a fresh asylum application on DATE . On DATE the Secretary of ORG refused to consider his further representations as amounting to a new asylum application . The general situation in GPE did not indicate any personal risk of ill - treatment and there was no evidence that he would be personally affected upon return . The fact that he had been away from GPE for DATE suggested that he would hardly be of any interest to the Sri NORP authorities .
CARDINAL . His application for permission to apply for judicial review was refused on DATE on the papers by Mr Justice PERSON who stated :

“ There is no question but that the situation in GPE has deteriorated over DATE and to such an extent that there is a real prospect [ that the full scale war between the ORG and the authorities will recommence . However , that does not of itself mean that no - one can be returned . The adjudicator accepted the claimant ’s account but noted that he had only been detained for short periods , possibly in general round ups , and had not assisted the NORP . All this was over DATE .

In the circumstances , it is not possible to say what has been happening creates a real risk of relevant ill - treatment for this claimant . Thus I do not think there is any arguable error of law in the defendant ’s decision . ”
CARDINAL . The applicant ’s renewed application was refused by Mr Justice PERSON at an oral hearing on DATE .

CARDINAL . The applicant was then issued with removal directions for DATE . On DATE , he made further representations to the Secretary of ORG arguing , inter alia , that removal would be incompatible with his rights guaranteed by the LAW . When the Secretary of ORG did not respond , on DATE the applicant sought to challenge this failure by judicial review .

CARDINAL . It appears that DATE , the Secretary of ORG did in fact reject these representations as not amounting to a fresh claim . The Secretary of ORG relied on the findings of the Adjudicator and the observations of Mr Justice PERSON of DATE . The Secretary of ORG also considered a paper submitted by the applicant which had been issued by the ORG High Commissioner for Refugees ( ORG ) on DATE , entitled “ FAC on ORG from GPE ” ( “ the ORG Position Paper ” see paragraphs CARDINAL–CARDINAL below ) . He found , however , that the paper was general in nature and therefore little weight could be attached to it . Consideration was given to the applicant ’s claim that the political and security situation in GPE had worsened and whilst it was acknowledged that there had been some problems with the peace process , the NORP and the Sri NORP authorities were committed to peace and working towards an agreement . Notwithstanding QUANTITY bomb attacks in GPE , there was a “ distinct geographical limitation ” to recent incidents and it was open to the applicant to avoid the northern and eastern areas affected by the continuing operations of the GPE armed forces and the ORG . While there had been increasing levels of disappearances in GPE , progress had been made by the creation of an independent body to observe government investigations . The Secretary of ORG concluded that the points made in the applicant ’s submissions had not been previously considered , but taken with the materials considered in the original refusal of the applicant ’s asylum claim and the determination of his appeal by the Adjudicator , the new materials would not have created a realistic prospect of success and the submissions did not therefore amount to a fresh asylum claim .

CARDINAL . The applicant then made an out of hours application for an injunction to ORG . This was granted by Mr Justice PERSON and the removal directions in place for the same evening were cancelled . In his subsequent order of DATE , Mr Justice PERSON stated :

CARDINAL . On DATE Mrs Justice Black refused the applicant ’s application for permission to seek judicial review of the Secretary of ORG ’s alleged failure to consider and determine the new representations made on DATE . She stated :

“ In fact [ the Secretary of ORG ] did consider the further representations and , in a letter of DATE , refused to treat them as a fresh claim . Strictly speaking that disposes of the proposed [ judicial review ] application .

However , it is clear that the claimant seeks in fact to advance a more fundamental challenge to the removal directions on the basis that the situation in GPE has deteriorated since the matter was last considered and has reached a point where the claimant would be at risk on return . CARDINAL . The applicant then sought to renew his application for permission to apply for judicial review , submitting detailed amended grounds for his application on DATE . The oral hearing of the renewed application was listed for CARDINAL DATE but the applicant , appearing in person at the hearing , withdrew his application .

CARDINAL . In a subsequent letter of CARDINAL DATE from the applicant ’s solicitors at the time of the judicial review proceedings to his current representatives before ORG , the former stated that the reason the judicial review application was withdrawn was that they , the solicitors , were without instructions from the applicant . They were informed by counsel that this was a “ pre - LP ” case ( see paragraphs CARDINAL–CARDINAL below ) and counsel felt that there were insufficient merits in the case to proceed to the oral hearing .

By DATE , the President of the ORG had applied Rule CARDINAL in CARDINAL cases where NORP sought to prevent their removal to GPE from GPE . “ The Acting President has consulted the Judges of the Section about his concerns including as regards the strain which the processing of numerous Rule CARDINAL applications places on judicial time and resources . CARDINAL . The ORG has since applied Rule CARDINAL in respect of CARDINAL NORP applicants who claim that their return to GPE from GPE would expose them to ill - treatment in violation of LAW .

CARDINAL . Sections CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) and CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the Immigration Act DATE provide for the making of Immigration Rules by the Secretary of ORG . Paragraph CARDINAL of ORG ( ORG CARDINAL , as amended by ORG ) states that :

“ When a human rights or asylum claim has been refused and any appeal relating to that claim is no longer pending , the decision maker will consider any further submissions and , if rejected , will then determine whether they amount to a fresh claim . The submissions will amount to a fresh claim if they are significantly different from the material that has previously been considered . The submissions will only be significantly different if the content :

Section CARDINAL of LAW DATE provides that , in determining any question that arises in connection with a Convention right , courts and tribunals must take into account any case - law from this ORG so far as , in the opinion of the court or tribunal , it is relevant to the proceedings in which that question has arisen . CARDINAL . Judicial review in GPE and GPE is regulated by Part CARDINAL of ORG . Rule CARDINAL.CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) defines a claim for judicial review as a claim to review the lawfulness of an enactment or a decision , action or failure to act in relation to the exercise of a public function . An application for judicial review has CARDINAL stages . The first is an application for permission to apply for judicial review ; the second , if permission is granted , is a substantive application for judicial review . Where permission is refused without a hearing , under Rule CARDINAL.CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) and ( CARDINAL ) the claimant may not appeal but may within DATE request the decision to be reconsidered at a hearing . Rule CARDINAL provides that where permission to apply for judicial review has been refused at a hearing in ORG , the person seeking that permission may within DATE apply to ORG for permission to appeal .

CARDINAL . Appeals from decisions of the Secretary of ORG in asylum , immigration and nationality matters are now heard by ORG ( “ the ORG ” ) , which replaces the former system of ORG and ORG . Paragraph CARDINAL of the Practice Directions governing the operation of the ORG defines country guidance determinations of the ORG as follows :

“ CARDINAL.CARDINAL A reported determination of the [ ORG ] or of the ORG [ the former ORG ] bearing the letters “ CG ” shall be treated as an authoritative finding on the country guidance issue identified in the determination , based upon the evidence before the members of the [ ORG ] or the ORG that determined the appeal . As a result , unless it has been expressly superseded or replaced by any later “ CG ” determination , or is inconsistent with other authority that is binding on the [ ORG ] , such a country guidance case is authoritative in any subsequent appeal , so far as that appeal :
( a ) NORP relates to the country guidance issue in question ; and
( b ) depends upon the same or similar evidence .

CARDINAL Because of the principle that like cases should be treated in like manner , any failure to follow a clear , apparently applicable country guidance case or to show why it does not apply to the case in question is likely to be regarded as grounds for review or appeal on a point of law . ”

CARDINAL . In the above country guidance determination promulgated on DATE , the ORG considered the case of a GPE , ORG , from GPE in the north of GPE . He had experienced problems with the NORP and the Sri NORP authorities and fled GPE on DATE but had been refused asylum in GPE by the Secretary of ORG . Since the case had been identified as a country guidance determination , the ORG heard evidence from a number of experts on the situation in GPE and the treatment of NORP there . It also considered the UNCHR Position Paper ( see paragraphs CARDINAL–CARDINAL below ) and considered evidence on LOC treatment of returned failed asylum seekers at FAC , including a series of letters from ORG in GPE and a report of ORG ( see paragraphs PERSON and CARDINAL below ) . In dismissing ORG ’s appeal on asylum grounds but allowing it on the basis of LAW , the ORG gave the following guidance in the headnote to its determination :

“ ( CARDINAL ) NORP are not per se at risk of serious harm from the Sri NORP authorities in GPE . A number of factors may increase the risk , including but not limited to : a previous record as a suspected or actual ORG member ; a previous criminal record and/or outstanding arrest warrant ; bail jumping and/or escaping from custody ; having signed a confession or similar document ; having been asked by the security forces to become an informer ; the presence of scarring ; return from GPE or other centre of NORP fundraising ; illegal departure from GPE ; lack of an ORG card or other documentation ; having made an asylum claim abroad ; having relatives in the ORG . In every case , those factors and the weight to be ascribed to them , individually and cumulatively , must be considered in the light of the facts of each case but they are not intended to be a check list .
( CARDINAL ) NORP If a person is actively wanted by the police and/or named on a Watched or Wanted list held at FAC , they may be at risk of detention at the airport .
( CARDINAL ) Otherwise , the majority of returning failed asylum seekers are processed relatively quickly and with no difficulty beyond some possible harassment .

( CARDINAL ) NORP in GPE are at increased risk of being stopped at checkpoints , in a cordon and search operation , or of being the subject of a raid on a ORG where they are staying . In general , the risk again is no more than harassment and should not cause any lasting difficulty , but NORP who have recently returned to GPE and have not yet renewed their GPE identity documents will be subject to more investigation and the factors listed above may then come into play .
( CARDINAL ) Returning NORP should be able to establish the fact of their recent return during the short period necessary for new identity documents to be procured .

( CARDINAL ) A person who can not establish that he is at real risk of persecution in his home area is not a refugee ; but his appeal may succeed under LAW ORG , or he may be entitled to humanitarian protection if he can establish he would be at risk in the part of the country to which he will be returned .

( CARDINAL ) The weight to be given to expert evidence ( individual or country ) and country background evidence is dependent upon the quality of the raw data from which it is drawn and the quality of the filtering process to which that data has been subjected . Sources should be given whenever possible .
( CARDINAL) The determinations about GPE listed in para CARDINAL [ of the determination – see below ] are replaced as country guidance by this determination . They continue to be reported cases . ”
CARDINAL . In its consideration of the expert evidence before it , the ORG heard argument on the correct approach to ORG ( see paragraphs DATE below ) . It stated that :

“ CARDINAL . The ORG report was very topical and up to date . We agree with the general submission made by [ counsel for the Secretary of ORG ] that the protection agenda of the ORG is a wider CARDINAL than the mere assessment of refugee or subsidiary protection status . However , these reports are prepared by persons with direct experience of the core issues involved and thus we accord them substantive weight in this case . ”

CARDINAL . The ORG then considered each of the CARDINAL risk factors that had been identified by the appellant , ORG , and which it had summarised in its headnote . In respect of NORP ethnicity , the ORG recalled that NORP comprised PERCENT of the population of GPE , which called for caution when assessing risk in GPE , especially GPE . There was a need for knowledge of where applicants came from in GPE and their involvement or lack of it with GPE organisations , whether voluntary , involuntary or otherwise . It found that there were different risk profiles for sub - groups of those with NORP ethnicity ( GPE NORP coming from the north or east compared with “ NORP ” , “ Plantation ” or “ LOC NORP ) . Age and gender had to be taken into account and young male NORP in GPE , particularly in GPE , were at a relatively higher level of risk . There was a higher propensity on the part of the GPE authorities to target young men and women from the north and the east in a period of virtual civil war .

CARDINAL . In respect of a previous record as a suspected or actual ORG member or supporter , it was of vital importance to establish an applicant ’s profile and the credibility of his background in some depth . If he or she was not credible as to his claim to come from the north or east , which left a situation where he could be a GPE from GPE with little or no involvement with the NORP , there could be little risk .

CARDINAL . A previous criminal record and/or arrest warrant was , in the ORG ’s view , a significant factor that needed to be taken into account in the assessment of the totality of the risk but did not mean , of itself , that the applicant had a well - founded fear of persecution or other significant harm on return to GPE for that reason alone . The issue was to establish the credibility of the criminal record , or an arrest warrant , and decide whether it was reasonably likely to exist in respect of the applicant .
CARDINAL . Those who had jumped bail or absconded from police custody , the ORG noted :

“ We agree with the logic that those who have been released after going to court and released from custody on formal bail are reasonably likely , on the evidence , to be not only recorded on the police records as bail jumpers but obviously on the court records as well . Thus we would identify those in the situation such as this appellant who have been found to have been to court in GPE , and subsequently released on formal bail , as having a profile that could place them at a higher level of risk of being identified from police computers at the airport . Their treatment thereafter will of course depend upon the basis that they were detained in the first place . It is important to note that we did not have before us any information as to the treatment of bail jumpers from the ordinary criminal justice system , and there may be many of them , when they again come to the attention of the authorities , be they GPE or NORP . We had no evidence that NORP bail jumpers are treated differently from NORP ones . Clearly punishment for jumping bail will not make someone a refugee . As we have said , the risk of detention and maltreatment will depend on the profile of the individual applicant . ”

For those who had not been brought to court and had possibly been released from detention after payment of a bribe , much would depend on the evidence relating to the formality of the detention . If the detention was informal and there were no records of a bribe , the risk level would be likely to be below that of a real risk . On this risk factor , the ORG concluded :

“ While we would agree that there may well be situations where NORP , with little or no profile related to the NORP , or other ‘ GPE groups , could be briefly detained and harassed , as no doubt happens in round ups in GPE and elsewhere , we consider it illogical to assume that an escapee , from GPE government detention , or a bail jumper from the GPE court system , would be merely ‘ harassed’ given the climate of torture with impunity that is repeatedly confirmed as existent in the background material from all sources . We consider , ( as we think it does in the appellant ’s particular case ) , that the totality of the evidence may point to a real risk , in some cases , of persecution or really serious harm when a recorded escapee or bail jumper is discovered , on return to GPE . ”

CARDINAL . When an applicant had signed a confession , this could be a significant risk factor and the ORG noted expert evidence to the effect that many NORP were released after signing statements made in NORP that they often did not understand . The factor had to be considered in the totality of the risk . Equally , when an applicant had refused requests by the security services to become an informer against the NORP , there was a higher risk that they would be assumed to be a collaborator of the NORP but such evidence had to be taken into account with the totality of the evidence and merely establishing that an applicant had refused to become an informer would not be in every case the basis for a valid asylum claim on its own .
CARDINAL . On the risk arising from the presence of scarring on an applicant , the ORG stated :

“ CARDINAL . The background evidence on the issue of scarring has fluctuated . Up until the time of the ceasefire it was generally accepted as something which the Sri NORP authorities noted and took into account both at the airport and on detention and in strip searches of suspected ORG supporters . Their perception that it may indicate training by the ORG , or participation in active warfare , was self - evident , and simply was ‘ good’ policing , as appeared to be suggested by ORG in his discussions with PERSON [ one of the experts on GPE from whom the ORG heard evidence ] . On the same logic it was also valid to conclude that the impact of scarring was of far less interest during DATE while the ceasefire agreement was having some effective impact . The evidence that was provided in this case , including that from PERSON following his discussions with the Inspector General of Police ( paragraph CARDINAL of his report ) , the ORG [ ORG ] letter of DATE , and the ORG [ GPE and ORG on GPE ] all indicate that scarring may again be relevant . We agree with the comments in PERSON report , that the issue of scarring was considered by the police to be a very serious indicator of whether a GPE might have been involved in the LTTE . However , on the evidence now before us we consider that the scarring issue should be one that only has significance when there are other factors that would bring an applicant to the attention of the authorities , either at the airport or subsequently in GPE , such as being wanted on an outstanding arrest warrant or a lack of identity . We therefore agree with the ORG remarks that it may be a relevant , but not an overriding , factor . Thus , whilst the presence of scarring may promote interest in a young GPE under investigation by the GPE authorities , we do not consider that , merely because a young GPE has scars , he will automatically be ill - treated in detention . ”

CARDINAL . In respect of the risk arising from return from GPE or another centre of NORP activity or fund - raising , the ORG heard evidence from ORG activities and fund - raising in GPE . It concluded that this factor was highly case - specific and any applicant would need to show the extent to which ORG in GPE was aware of his activities and was thus likely to have passed the information on to GPE when the applicant was being deported or removed .

CARDINAL . Illegal departure from GPE did not of necessity establish a well founded fear of persecution or serious harm , although in the “ heightened level of insecurity ” in GPE it would add to the risk profile . Similarly , given the number of “ cordon and search ” operations by ORG , the lack of a valid identity card could contribute towards an increased level of risk . In the ORG ’s view , it had to be coupled with other risk factors for those of NORP ethnicity but it was a contributing factor . An applicant would need to show why he would be at continuing risk and that he could not reasonably be expected to obtain a new identity card .

CARDINAL . In respect of the risk factor of having made an asylum claim abroad , the ORG relied , inter alia , on a letter dated DATE from ORG in GPE ( see also paragraphs CARDINAL–CARDINAL below ) which had stated that lists of failed asylum seekers could form part of search operations in GPE ( at DATE and CARDINAL of the determination ) . The ORG found that it was a reasonable inference that application forms for replacement passports and travel documents might alert ORG in GPE and that information could be passed on . However , the ORG did not consider having made a failed asylum claim abroad to be an issue that alone would place a returnee at real risk on return . It would be a contributing factor that would need other , perhaps more compelling factors before a real risk could be established .

CARDINAL . The ORG considered that the fact of having relatives in the ORG was a logical factor but needed to be taking into account with the totality of other evidence and the profile of other family members . On its own , without established and credible evidence of the details of the other family members and their known role or involvement with the NORP , it would be of limited weight . When assessing those who have relatives who were members of the NORP , it was not only important to consider the relationship , and the involvement of the relative but whether , and to what extent , knowledge of the relative ’s activities were likely to have been known to the security forces in GPE . This would vary depending on the relative ’s profile and whether or not he or she had been previously detained . The question of how the authorities would know that an individual was so related might also be of concern .
CARDINAL . In its conclusion on the risk profile for NORP , the ORG stated :

“ CARDINAL . Our assessment of the various risk factors above has highlighted that each case must be determined on its own facts . It may be that in some credible cases CARDINAL of these individual risk factors on its own will establish a real risk of persecution or serious harm on return by the Sri NORP authorities for GPE NORP who are failed asylum seekers from GPE . For those with a lower profile , assessed on one or a combination of the risk factors we have noted however , such as this appellant , their specific profiles must be assessed in each situation and set against the above non - exhaustive and non - conclusive , set of risk factors and the volatile country situation . As can be noted , several factors , such as being subject to an outstanding arrest warrant , or a proven bail jumper from a formal bail hearing may establish a much higher level of propensity to risk than various other factors . In this situation therefore , the assessment exercise is a much larger and more detailed one than may have been the situation up to DATE and certainly during the period of the cease fire agreement ( ‘ CFA’ ) . The current worsening situation in GPE requires serious consideration of all of the above factors , a review of up to date country of origin information set against the very carefully assessed profile of the appellant . ”
CARDINAL . In addressing the general situation in GPE at the time and the possible of relocation of NORP from the north or east to GPE , the ORG stated :
